Description: Terracotta female figure with flat back.Fragment of body only, missing head and feet. Naked woman standing with long shoulder length black hair. Painted decoration in black and red. Red fabric with buff surfaces.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Rhodian parallels of Daedalic type dated mid to late 7th century BC (Higgins 1970, nos 16-18; 25-28). However, this style continues into the early-mid 6th century BC at Miletus (Jan Marc pers. comm). Similar plaques also made in Cyprus in the early 6th century BC (Karageorghis 1999, pl.LXXV. 9 X(vi)78). Karageorghis, J. 1999. The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus.V. The Cypro-Archaic Period small female figurines. Nicosia, University of Cyprus.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.004) (Phase 3)
